elements.content: Single-ionic conducting electrolytes are important for the improvement of lithium metal batteries with high energy density and safety. Herein, we propose a new strategy to anchor a large anionic group on the skeleton of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and achieve preeminent single-ionic conducting electrolytes. Utilizing a postsynthetic modification method, the trifluoromethanesulfonyl group is covalently coordinated to the amino groups of the UiO-66-NH2 framework. Such a single-ionic conducting solid-state electrolyte (SSE) has a high ionic conductivity (2.07 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 25 °C), a low activation energy of 0.31 eV, a wide electrochemical window up to 4.52 V, as well as a high Li+ transference number of 0.84. Simultaneously, it can effectively inhibit the formation of lithium dendrite. Solid-state batteries assembled with LiFePO4 as the cathode exhibit outstanding rate performance and cyclic stability, especially for low-temperature Li-metal batteries at 0 °C with trace amounts of propylene carbonate as wetting agents. More importantly, the corresponding all-solid-state batteries based on an MOF-based SSE also have nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency at different current densities.

elements.content: Energy shortage and environmental pollution present severe challenges to modern energy storage methods. It is imperative to develop high energy density and safety power sources. Solid-state lithium metal batteries have been deemed to be promising candidates for the next generation of energy storage devices. One of the key technologies of such devices is the development of solid-state electrolytes (SSEs). Over the past 60 years, inorganic SSEs are mainly composed of inorganic ceramics/glass and organic polymers. The inorganic ceramics/glass electrolytes such as garnet-type Li5La3Z2O12, perovskite-type Li3x La2/3–x TiO3, and sulfide-type glass have been widely studied because of their high ionic conductivity (10–4 to 10–2 S cm–1). However, these electrolytes are not suitable for commercialization because of poor machining performance and high interface impedance with electrodes. Correspondingly, organic polymer electrolytes such as poly­(ethylene oxide) (PEO), poly­(vinyl chloride), poly­(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), and poly­(methyl methacrylate) are considered to be the most promising SSEs in lithium metal batteries because of their excellent flexibility and processability. Unfortunately, they are limited by low ionic conductivity (10–8 to 10–5 S cm–1) in rechargeable secondary batteries at room temperature. In addition, ionic gel such as conductors blending with nanotubes, silica, and ionic liquid crystalline electrolytes are popular because of their outstanding ionic conductivity. Disturbingly, the low ion transference number and expensive precursors of these electrolytes also hinder their potential application.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Energy shortage and environmental pollution present severe challenges to modern energy storage methods. It is imperative to develop high energy density and safety power sources. Solid-state lithium metal batteries have been deemed to be promising candidates for the next generation of energy storage devices. One of the key technologies of such devices is the development of solid-state electrolytes (SSEs). Over the past 60 years, inorganic SSEs are mainly composed of inorganic ceramics/glass and organic polymers. The inorganic ceramics/glass electrolytes such as garnet-type Li5La3Z2O12, perovskite-type Li3x La2/3-x TiO3, and sulfide-type glass have been widely studied because of their high ionic conductivity (10-4 to 10-2 S cm-1). However, these electrolytes are not suitable for commercialization because of poor machining performance and high interface impedance with electrodes. Correspondingly, organic polymer electrolytes such as poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO), poly(vinyl chloride), poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), and poly(methyl methacrylate) are considered to be the most promising SSEs in lithium metal batteries because of their excellent flexibility and processability. Unfortunately, they are limited by low ionic conductivity (10-8 to 10-5 S cm-1) in rechargeable secondary batteries at room temperature. In addition, ionic gel such as conductors blending with nanotubes, silica, and ionic liquid crystalline electrolytes are popular because of their outstanding ionic conductivity. Disturbingly, the low ion transference number and expensive precursors of these electrolytes also hinder their potential application.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as a new type of SSEs, have received extensive concern as they can integrate the advantages and avoid the disadvantages of inorganic and organic electrolytes. MOF-based SSEs have the following advantages: (1) the adjustable porous structure provides a unique channel for lithium-ion transport. (2) Nanosized MOF particles increase the contact between the electrolyte and the electrode interface, thus promoting ion transport kinetics. (3) Some functional groups with high ionic conductivity and interface stability can be introduced into MOF structures by covalent bond modification to improve the electrochemical performance. (4) The open metal sites of the MOF structure have been shown to bind anions, thus restricting anion movement. The first MOF-based SSE with high ionic conductivity (3.1 × 10–4 S cm–1) was reported by Long et al. in 2011, combining with the metal sites and transmission channels. However, the metal sites in MOFs are usually occupied by carboxylic acids or nitrogen-containing ligands and there are no excessive sites to bind and transport Li cations, leading to low ionic conductivity of most MOF-based SSEs. To our knowledge, only a few MOF-based electrolytes were applied to assemble into solid-state batteries. In addition, the polarization of solid-state batteries assembled by MOF-based electrolytes is a more serious question because of the lower Li+ transference number. All these obstacles must be overcome before the MOF-based electrolytes are applied for the commercialized Li-metal batteries.

elements.content: Here, we propose a new strategy and synthesize a novel anionic MOF-based single-ion conducting electrolyte by the postsynthetic modification (PSM) method, in which the trifluoromethylsulfonyl (Tf) group with ion transport property is covalently grafted onto the skeleton of UiO-66-NH2. Because of the strong electron-absorbing effect of the OSO group in Tf, the charge delocalization of a nitrogen atom is enhanced, thus reducing the formation of the lithium-ion pair. In addition, the nanosized MOF-based single-ionic conducting electrolytes can effectively increase the contact between electrolytes and electrodes, thus promoting the interfacial ion transport kinetics. Most impressively, the electrolyte exhibits a splendid ionic conductivity (2.07 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 25 °C), high Li+ transference number (0.84), and effective inhibiting effect for the growth of lithium dendrite. On the basis of the above advantages, the batteries assembled by this SSE have prominent electrochemical performance at low temperature and room temperature. This electrolyte offers the possibility for the practical application of MOF-based electrolytes.

elements.content: The preparation of UiO-66-NH2 was according to a modified reported hydrothermal method. In general, HfCl4 (1.7 g, 5.2 mmol) and 2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.906 g, 5 mmol) were added to 50 mL of a mixed solution of deionized water and acetic acid (volume ratio of 3:2). The mixed solution was refluxed at 100 °C in an oil bath for 24 h to yield light yellow solid powders. The products were collected and washed three times with water, which was activated by heating at 80 °C in vacuum for use.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of UiO-66-NH2 

The preparation of UiO-66-NH2 was according to a modified reported hydrothermal method. In general, HfCl4 (1.7 g, 5.2 mmol) and 2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.906 g, 5 mmol) were added to 50 mL of a mixed solution of deionized water and acetic acid (volume ratio of 3:2). The mixed solution was refluxed at 100 °C in an oil bath for 24 h to yield light yellow solid powders. The products were collected and washed three times with water, which was activated by heating at 80 °C in vacuum for use.

elements.content: To a nanocrystal of UiO-66-NH2 (0.38 g, 1.0 mmol) and triethylamine (0.1518 g, 1.5 mmol) in anhydrous dichloromethane (20 mL) at 0 °C was slowly added trifluoromethanesulfonic anhydride (0.3385 g, 1.2 mmol), and then pyridine (0.0791 g, 1.0 mmol) was added dropwise under stirring conditions. The mixture was maintained at 0 °C for 30 min and then reacted at ambient temperature for 72 h. After the reactions, the sample was collected by centrifugation for further use.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 

To a nanocrystal of UiO-66-NH2 (0.38 g, 1.0 mmol) and triethylamine (0.1518 g, 1.5 mmol) in anhydrous dichloromethane (20 mL) at 0 °C was slowly added trifluoromethanesulfonic anhydride (0.3385 g, 1.2 mmol), and then pyridine (0.0791 g, 1.0 mmol) was added dropwise under stirring conditions. The mixture was maintained at 0 °C for 30 min and then reacted at ambient temperature for 72 h. After the reactions, the sample was collected by centrifugation for further use.

elements.content: The potassium salt form of UiO-66-NSO2CF3K was obtained by neutralization. To a suspended solution of UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 (0.512 g, 1.0 mmol) in deionized water (20 mL) was gradually added slightly excessive K2CO3 powder (0.166 g, 1.2 mmol) at room temperature with stirring for 12 h. The sample was obtained by filtration, and washed two times with water and then heated in 80 °C vacuum overnight.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of UiO-66-NSO2CF3K (UiOKTFSI)

The potassium salt form of UiO-66-NSO2CF3K was obtained by neutralization. To a suspended solution of UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 (0.512 g, 1.0 mmol) in deionized water (20 mL) was gradually added slightly excessive K2CO3 powder (0.166 g, 1.2 mmol) at room temperature with stirring for 12 h. The sample was obtained by filtration, and washed two times with water and then heated in 80 °C vacuum overnight.

elements.content: The UiOLiTFSI was obtained by ion exchange reaction. The UiO-66-NSO2CF3K (0.55 g, 1.0 mmol) was placed into anhydrous CH3CN (20 mL) in a round-bottom flask, to which was gradually added LiClO4 (0.128 g, 1.2 mmol) at room temperature with stirring for 12 h. The product was filtered and washed with anhydrous acetonitrile several times. Then, the sample was ion-exchanged three times by the same method. Finally, the UiOLiTFSI was obtained by drying at 120 °C in vacuum overnight.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of MOF-Based Single-Ion Conductors (UiOLiTFSI)

The UiOLiTFSI was obtained by ion exchange reaction. The UiO-66-NSO2CF3K (0.55 g, 1.0 mmol) was placed into anhydrous CH3CN (20 mL) in a round-bottom flask, to which was gradually added LiClO4 (0.128 g, 1.2 mmol) at room temperature with stirring for 12 h. The product was filtered and washed with anhydrous acetonitrile several times. Then, the sample was ion-exchanged three times by the same method. Finally, the UiOLiTFSI was obtained by drying at 120 °C in vacuum overnight.

elements.content: The UiO-66 was prepared according to a reported method. Typically, terephthalic acid (0.83 g, 5 mmol) and HfCl4 (1.6 g, 5 mmol) were dissolved in 40 mL of mixed solution of dimethylformamide (DMF) and formic acid (volume ratio of 9:1). The mixed solution was put into a stainless-steel autoclave and then heated at 120 °C for 48 h. The product was collected and dried in vacuum at 120 °C; then, it was transferred to the acetonitrile solution of 1 M LiClO4 and stirred for 12 h. The LiUiO-66 obtained was filtered and collected, which was dried by heating at 120 °C in vacuum for use.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of LiUiO-66 (UiOLi)

The UiO-66 was prepared according to a reported method. Typically, terephthalic acid (0.83 g, 5 mmol) and HfCl4 (1.6 g, 5 mmol) were dissolved in 40 mL of mixed solution of dimethylformamide (DMF) and formic acid (volume ratio of 9:1). The mixed solution was put into a stainless-steel autoclave and then heated at 120 °C for 48 h. The product was collected and dried in vacuum at 120 °C; then, it was transferred to the acetonitrile solution of 1 M LiClO4 and stirred for 12 h. The LiUiO-66 obtained was filtered and collected, which was dried by heating at 120 °C in vacuum for use.

elements.content: The handled MOFs (UiOLiTFSI and UiOLi) and LiTFSI were dried at 70 °C under vacuum for 16 h before use. The Li/UiOLiTFSI and Li/UiOLi electrolytes were prepared by the mixture of the handled MOFs powder and LiTFSI (7:3 weight ratio), and pressed into 1.3 cm pellet at 300 MPa. The electrolyte surface was sanded smooth for further electrochemical tests.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Hybrid SSEs

The handled MOFs (UiOLiTFSI and UiOLi) and LiTFSI were dried at 70 °C under vacuum for 16 h before use. The Li/UiOLiTFSI and Li/UiOLi electrolytes were prepared by the mixture of the handled MOFs powder and LiTFSI (7:3 weight ratio), and pressed into 1.3 cm pellet at 300 MPa. The electrolyte surface was sanded smooth for further electrochemical tests.

elements.content: UiOLiTFSI and LiTFSI (7:3 weight ratio) were dissolved in DMF, and 20% PVDF was put into the mixture by mechanical stirring at room temperature for 12 h. Then, the dispersed mixture was cast to a Teflon mold. Finally, the electrolyte membrane was dried in a vacuum furnace at 80 °C for 24 h to remove the leftover solvent. The as-prepared membrane (PL/UiOLiTFSI, ≈70 μm in thickness) was cut into free-standing and flexible sheets with 16 mm diameter and kept in a glove box filled with argon. Similarly, the corresponding solid electrolyte membrane (PL/UiOLi) and intrinsic single ionic conductor electrolyte membrane (P/UiOLiTFSI) without lithium salt (LiTFSI) were prepared by a similar process.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of PL/MOFs and P/MOFs Electrolyte Membranes

UiOLiTFSI and LiTFSI (7:3 weight ratio) were dissolved in DMF, and 20% PVDF was put into the mixture by mechanical stirring at room temperature for 12 h. Then, the dispersed mixture was cast to a Teflon mold. Finally, the electrolyte membrane was dried in a vacuum furnace at 80 °C for 24 h to remove the leftover solvent. The as-prepared membrane (PL/UiOLiTFSI, ~70 μm in thickness) was cut into free-standing and flexible sheets with 16 mm diameter and kept in a glove box filled with argon. Similarly, the corresponding solid electrolyte membrane (PL/UiOLi) and intrinsic single ionic conductor electrolyte membrane (P/UiOLiTFSI) without lithium salt (LiTFSI) were prepared by a similar process.

elements.content: Ionic conductivity σ (S cm–1) of the electrolyte pellets (Li/UiOLiTFSI and Li/UiOLi) was tested by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) with the frequency ranging from 0.1 Hz to 7 MHz. The solid electrolyte pellets were sandwiched between two silver-coated stainless-steel block electrodes. The ionic conductivity (σ) was calculated as per the following formula ()­ σ = L R × S where L (cm) is the thickness of the electrolyte, R (Ω) and S (cm2) are the bulk resistance and area of the electrolyte, respectively. The electrochemical window was determined by linear sweep voltammograms (LSV) using Li|electrolytes|SS cells, and the scanning rate of 0.2 mV s–1. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) behaviors of SSE membranes were tested on Li|electrolytes|SS cells by Versa STAT 3 (Princeton Applied Research) with the voltage range of −0.2 to 5 V, and the scanning rate of 0.2 mV s–1. The Li+ transference number (t Li+ ) has been measured using the Bruce–Vincent–Evans method in a Li|electrolyte|Li cell; 5 μL of propylene carbonate (PC) solvent was dripped onto the electrolyte/electrode interface. The symmetric battery was polarized with a dc voltage of 10 mV and the t Li+ can be calculated as per t L i + = I s ( Δ V − I 0 R 0 ) I 0 ( Δ V − I s R s ) where ΔV is the dc polarization voltage, I 0 and I s are initial and steady stable current before and after polarization, respectively. R 0 and R s are initial and steady stable resistance before and after polarization. Lithium stripping/plating was implemented on a Li symmetrical cells with 5 μL PC solvent using a LAND battery cycler.

elements.content: For the electrochemical performance test of solid-state cells, the cathode was prepared by grinding with 70% LiFePO4 (LFP), 20% carbon black, and 10% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) in 2 mL of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone for 1 h to form a uniform slurry. The prepared slurry was coated on an aluminum foil and dried in vacuum at 55 °C for 20 h. The mass loading of LFP in the cathode pellets was 2.0–2.5 mg cm–2. Then, the LFP cathode and lithium foil were assembled in CR2025 coin cell in the glovebox. The charge–discharge experiments were measured between 2.7 and 4 V at low temperature and room temperature.
elements.clean_text: For the electrochemical performance test of solid-state cells, the cathode was prepared by grinding with 70% LiFePO4 (LFP), 20% carbon black, and 10% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) in 2 mL of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone for 1 h to form a uniform slurry. The prepared slurry was coated on an aluminum foil and dried in vacuum at 55 °C for 20 h. The mass loading of LFP in the cathode pellets was 2.0-2.5 mg cm-2. Then, the LFP cathode and lithium foil were assembled in CR2025 coin cell in the glovebox. The charge-discharge experiments were measured between 2.7 and 4 V at low temperature and room temperature.

elements.content: The synthesis of MOF-based single-ionic conductor is shown in Figure S1. First, the Tf-modified MOF was synthesized by UiO-66-NH2 nanoparticles and trifluoromethanesulfonic anhydride (Tf2O) in solvent conditions for 72 h. Then, the product was neutralized in excess K2CO3 aqueous solution. Lastly, the acetonitrile solution of LiClO4 was used for ion exchange. The structure and working mechanism of the MOF-based single-ion conductor are shown in a. The regular octahedron is composed of Hf6O4(OH)4 nodes and organic ligands, which exhibits high porosity, thermal stability, and electrochemical stability. In addition, the lithium ion has a regular transport path in the channel. The structural integrities of the modified MOFs were evidenced by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, b), implying that they still maintain a perfect crystalline and topological structure after modification. The infrared (IR) spectrum of UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 clearly showed the existence of the Tf group (c); the characteristic absorption peaks at 1260 and 1573 cm–1 were corresponding to C–N stretching and CC vibration absorption peaks, respectively. The two absorption peaks at 1628 and 1385 cm–1 are classified as the asymmetric and symmetric stretching of carboxylate groups. The two distinct new absorption peaks at 1170 and 1032 cm–1 were ascribed to OSO symmetric and antisymmetric stretching, respectively. In addition, the formation of single ionic salts resulted in the shift of characteristic peaks at 1032 cm–1. 19F NMR spectrum also confirmed the Tf group in the UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 (Figure S2), and the characteristic peak at −73 ppm was the F signal in the −CF3 group. Meanwhile, the nitrogen adsorption at 77 K further confirmed that the introduction of new groups into the MOF skeleton leads to a significant decrease in pore volume and specific surface area. Also, the specific surface areas of UiO-66, UiO-66-NH2, and UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 were determined to be 1193, 1037, and 266 m2 g–1, respectively (Figure S3). To prove the existence of the N–S bond, UiO-66-NH2 and UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 were tested by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The results showed that there were new characteristic peaks at 401.6 eV in the N 1s spectra of anion-grafted UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 (Figure S4). At the same time, compared with the N 1s spectra of UiO-66-NH2, the N 1s peaks of UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 moved slightly toward the direction of low binding energy, suggesting that the peak at 401.6 eV is caused by the existence of the N–S bond. The thermogravimetry (TG) curve of UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 showed that the skeleton collapsed in the range 330–400 °C, and the DSC curve exhibited a corresponding endothermic peak in the same range. Besides, no phase transition was found before 330 °C (Figure S5). The ICP-MS analysis of UiOLiTFSI confirmed that the molar ratio of Li/Hf was about 2:3. When excessive LiClO4 was added, this ratio did not increase, suggesting that the nitrogen atoms and lithium ions in UiOLiTFSI had strong binding capacity. All these results clearly indicate that the Tf group is successfully anchored on the skeleton UiO-66-NH2 by PSM.

Results and Discussion

The synthesis of MOF-based single-ionic conductor is shown in Figure S1. First, the Tf-modified MOF was synthesized by UiO-66-NH2 nanoparticles and trifluoromethanesulfonic anhydride (Tf2O) in solvent conditions for 72 h. Then, the product was neutralized in excess K2CO3 aqueous solution. Lastly, the acetonitrile solution of LiClO4 was used for ion exchange. The structure and working mechanism of the MOF-based single-ion conductor are shown in a. The regular octahedron is composed of Hf6O4(OH)4 nodes and organic ligands, which exhibits high porosity, thermal stability, and electrochemical stability. In addition, the lithium ion has a regular transport path in the channel. The structural integrities of the modified MOFs were evidenced by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, b), implying that they still maintain a perfect crystalline and topological structure after modification. The infrared (IR) spectrum of UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 clearly showed the existence of the Tf group (c); the characteristic absorption peaks at 1260 and 1573 cm-1 were corresponding to C-N stretching and CC vibration absorption peaks, respectively. The two absorption peaks at 1628 and 1385 cm-1 are classified as the asymmetric and symmetric stretching of carboxylate groups. The two distinct new absorption peaks at 1170 and 1032 cm-1 were ascribed to OSO symmetric and antisymmetric stretching, respectively. In addition, the formation of single ionic salts resulted in the shift of characteristic peaks at 1032 cm-1. 19F NMR spectrum also confirmed the Tf group in the UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 (Figure S2), and the characteristic peak at -73 ppm was the F signal in the -CF3 group. Meanwhile, the nitrogen adsorption at 77 K further confirmed that the introduction of new groups into the MOF skeleton leads to a significant decrease in pore volume and specific surface area. Also, the specific surface areas of UiO-66, UiO-66-NH2, and UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 were determined to be 1193, 1037, and 266 m2 g-1, respectively (Figure S3). To prove the existence of the N-S bond, UiO-66-NH2 and UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 were tested by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The results showed that there were new characteristic peaks at 401.6 eV in the N 1s spectra of anion-grafted UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 (Figure S4). At the same time, compared with the N 1s spectra of UiO-66-NH2, the N 1s peaks of UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 moved slightly toward the direction of low binding energy, suggesting that the peak at 401.6 eV is caused by the existence of the N-S bond. The thermogravimetry (TG) curve of UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 showed that the skeleton collapsed in the range 330-400 °C, and the DSC curve exhibited a corresponding endothermic peak in the same range. When excessive LiClO4 was added, this ratio did not increase, suggesting that the nitrogen atoms and lithium ions in UiOLiTFSI had strong binding capacity. All these results clearly indicate that the Tf group is successfully anchored on the skeleton UiO-66-NH2 by PSM.

elements.content: To evaluate the Li+ ionic conductivities of MOF-based single-ion conductors, powder samples were mixed with lithium salt (30% LiTFSI, Li/UiOLiTFSI) and mechanically pressed into pellets (about 550 μm thick, Figure S6a). The corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray mapping images showed that major elements were evenly distributed in the pellet electrolyte (Figure S6b–e). LiTFSI helps improve the interfacial impedance between MOF nanoparticles and provides lithium ion for MOF channels, which can effectively improve the ionic conductivity. At the same time, the solid-state 7Li NMR spectrum also proves that there are two different chemical environments for lithium ion (Figure S7). The ac impedance spectra of the Li/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte were measured at different temperatures (a). The EIS plot at 25 °C shows that the small arc occurring in the high-frequency region (7 MHz to 18 kHz) corresponds to the bulk impedance of the electrolyte, and the straight line in the low-frequency region (18 kHz to 0.1 Hz) is assigned to the interface impedance between the electrolyte and the blocking electrode. Moreover, the EIS plot of the corresponding Li/UiOLi electrolyte was also displayed (Figure S8). The ion conductivities of the Li/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte are 2.07 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 25 °C and 1.39 × 10–3 S cm–1 at 70 °C, which are higher than that of the Li/UiOLi electrolyte (7.95 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 25 °C) and most other porous crystalline material-based solid-state electrolytes (Table S1). The reason can be attributed to the fact that the fixed anions in UiOLiTFSI can separate the ion pairs of LiTFSI, increase the concentration of lithium ions, and improve the ionic conductivity. In addition, the EIS plot of the intrinsic single ionic conductors UiOLiTFSI and UiOLi electrolytes at 25 °C are shown in Figure S9. The ionic conductivities of UiOLiTFSI and UiOLi electrolytes are 1.33 × 10–5 and 8.27 × 10–6 S cm–1, respectively. It is also proved that the addition of lithium salts (LiTFSI) can improve the ionic conductivity. Temperature-dependent conductivity measurements revealed a typical Arrhenius-like activated behavior (b). The activation energies of Li/UiOLiTFSI and Li/UiOLi electrolytes are 0.31 and 0.37 eV, respectively, which are much lower than ceramic-based electrolyte LiPON–Li3PO4 (0.55 eV) and PEO-based polymer electrolyte (1.66 eV). With a high conductivity (10–4 S cm–1) and a low activation energy (less than 0.4 eV), the new Li/UiOLiTFSI solid electrolyte can be defined as a superionic conductor.

elements.content: Considering the practical application, we fabricated a flexible free-standing single-ion conductor membrane by mixing Li/UiOLiTFSI and Li/UiOLi with 20% polytetrafluoroethylene (PVDF) as a binder, and the membranes were named as PL/UiOLiTFSI and PL/UiOLi. As shown in Figure S10, the electrolyte membrane has excellent flexibility and mechanical strength. Meanwhile, the residual solvent in the electrolyte membrane was detected by the 1H NMR spectrum (Figure S11), and the peaks of the residual solvents (2.73, 2.89, and 7.95 ppm) were so weak that they could almost be ignored. The nanoparticles of Li/UiOLiTFSI were uniformly distributed in the PVDF matrix with a smooth surface, as evidenced by the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image and the thickness of the electrolyte membrane is about 60–70 μm (c–e), which was formed by the accumulation of UiOLiTFSI nanoparticles. The electrochemical window of PL/UiOLiTFSI and the corresponding PL/UiOLi electrolyte membranes were investigated through linear sweep voltammograms (LSV) at room temperature (f). The stainless steel and lithium sheets were used as working and reference electrodes, respectively. The stable voltage of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte is about 4.52 V, which is obviously higher than that of the PL/UiOLi electrolyte (≈4.13 V). The cyclic voltammertry (CV) test further confirmed the chemical stability of the electrolytes. As shown in Figure S13, a pair of reversible redox current peaks near 0 V represent the dissolution and deposition of lithium ions on the working electrode. The oxidation current peak near 4.52 V is attributed to the decomposition of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte, which is consistent with LSV results. However, the electrochemical window of the intrinsic single ionic conductor electrolyte (P/UiOLiTFSI) without lithium salt is 4.08 V (Figure S12). The broad electrochemical window and high electrochemical stability is conducive to the matching of cathode materials with high-voltage lithium batteries.

elements.content: Other key parameters for electrolyte materials, lithium-ion transport number (t Li+ ) of PL/UiOLiTFSI and PL/UiOLi were measured using Li|SSEs|Li symmetric cells by the Evans method at room temperature and calculated by the current–time curve and the ac impedance spectra before and after polarization. The t Li+ of PL/UiOLiTFSI was 0.84, which is higher than that of PL/UiOLi (0.59) and other reported porous crystalline materials (g, S15, and Table S1). The high t Li+ value is ascribed to the restricted movement of large anion groups (Tf) grafted on the MOF skeleton as well as super single-ion conducting property, which can effectively overcome the polarization of batteries caused by the anionic motion. Meanwhile, the result was also confirmed by galvanostatic charge and discharge. In addition, the lithium ion transport number (0.87) under solvent-free conditions was measured, as shown in Figure S14. Combining with high lithium-ion transport number and wide electrochemical window, the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte is suitable for practical application in solid-state batteries, especially for fast-charging solid-state lithium batteries.

elements.content: To investigate the practical application of the MOF-based electrolyte in lithium metal batteries, the dynamic stabilities of the Li/electrolyte interface were tested by galvanostatic cycling experiments of Li symmetric batteries. The positive and negative voltages represent lithium stripping and deposition, respectively. Despite their high ionic conductivity, sulfide electrolytes exhibit poor lithium stability because of high interfacial impedance and obvious interfacial reaction. In contrast, the MOF-based single ion conductor electrolytes exhibit excellent interfacial stability. As shown in a, the Li|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li cell exhibits an excellent cycle stability at a current density of 0.05 mA cm–2 at room temperature. The average polarization voltage response is as low as 0.02 V. Even at the cycle time up to 160 h, the cell remains stable and has no obvious irreversible fluctuation of polarization voltage. Also, the SEM image of the lithium electrode after the Li plating/stripping cycling test exhibits very smooth and dense surface morphology (d). When the current density increases to 0.075 mA cm–2 (b), 0.15 mA cm–2 (c), and 0.3 mA cm–2 (Figure S16), the polarization voltage increases slightly, but there is still no short-circuit behavior. As the current density increases to 0.4 mA cm–2, the polarization voltage increases significantly after 23 h until the battery is forced to stop (Figure S16). In addition, the symmetrical battery is short-circuited after 46 h at the current density of 0.05 mA cm–2 for the intrinsic single ionic conductor electrolyte (P/UiOLiTFSI) without lithium salt (Figure S17). With respect to the full battery, short circuit occurs after six cycles of battery cycle at a current density of 0.2 C (Figure S20). However, as shown in Figure S18, the Li|PL/UiOLi|Li cell has a higher polarization voltage and a larger voltage fluctuation compared with the Li|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li cell. This implies that the interface between the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte and lithium metal is unstable. Some stick-shaped lithium dendrites on the surface of Li metal electrode are obviously observed (e). This is because in the process of lithium deposition, cations near the lithium electrode are reduced by electrons from the surface of lithium electrodes, and anions are expelled by the electric field; when the salt concentration near the electrode drops to zero within a certain period of time (Sand’s time), the charge balance of the electrolyte is destroyed, thereby resulting in the growth of lithium dendrites. Therefore, because of the high t Li+ of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte, the concentration of Li+ near the lithium electrode can be increased and the Sand’s time can be prolonged, thus resulting in excellent interface stability and compatibility of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte. These results confirmed that the high lithium-ion transport number and good dynamic stability of electrolyte are responsible for restriction of Li dendrite growth and promotion of Li deposition uniformly. However, because of the existence of lithium salts, the addition of trace PC solvents will lead to high concentration of liquid electrolyte, which will promote the conduction of lithium ions. In order to avoid appeal factors, the lithium-stripping deposition experiment of the solventless PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte was tested. As shown in Figure S23, the symmetrical battery can be stable for 120 h at a current density of 0.025 mA cm–2. Therefore, the single ionic conductor electrolyte has excellent electrochemical stability.

elements.content: In order to show the potential application of the MOF-based single ionic conductor electrolyte in lithium battery, we assembled solid-state lithium batteries, with LFP cathode and Li anode, to evaluate the performance of MOF-based electrolytes. The LFP|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li battery exhibited an excellent cycling performance (a), delivering a capacity of 147.7 mA h g–1 after 100 cycles at room temperature (97.2% to the initial capacity of 152 mA h g–1). Moreover, the Coulombic efficiency was improved from 95.1% of the first cycle to 99.5% of the subsequent cycle, which indicated that the electrolyte and electrode had good interface stability. Moreover, the rate performances of the LFP|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li battery are 145, 141, 136 and 109 mA h g–1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, and 3.0 C, respectively (b). Even after 10 cycles at high rates at 3.0 C, the battery recovered the capacity of 140 mA h g–1 at 0.1 C, demonstrating a good reversibility. What is more, the polarization of the charge curve of the battery system assembled by the PL/UiOLi electrolyte is obviously larger than that of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte (c). In addition, this polarization behavior is also lower than that of other MOF-based electrolyte battery systems, which is attributed to the high Li+ transport number of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte compared with other MOF-based electrolytes. It is worth mentioning that the battery maintained 97.0% capacity intention after 500 cycles of charge–discharge at 1.0 C (d), showing a good long-term cycling performance. However, the batteries of the PL/UiOLi electrolyte system have a very large capacity attenuation after 50 cycles. Interestingly, solid-state batteries in both systems showed various degrees of capacity increase within the first few dozen cycles, possibly because of the fitting of electrode and electrolyte interfaces. Finally, the PXRD results of PL/UiOLiTFSI and PL/UiOLi electrolytes after 100 cycles show that the crystal structure and topological structure of MOFs are still perfectly maintained (Figure S19).

elements.content: Low-temperature performance is an important indicator of SSE because the traditional solid-state batteries can only work well at temperatures above room temperature. In order to study the adaptability of the MOF-based SSE under different temperatures, we investigated the electrochemical charge–discharge performance of the LFP|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li battery at 0 °C. To our satisfaction, the solid-state batteries assembled from the MOF-based SSE show high rate performance and discharge capacity at 0 °C. As the current rate increases to 2 C, the discharge capacity of solid-state batteries remains 56 mA h g–1 at 0 °C. As the current rate returns to 0.1 C, the discharge capacity approaches its initial capacity (a). The discharge capacity retention rates of the solid-state batteries for 90 cycles at 0.2 C (Figure S21), 120 cycles at 0.5 C (Figure S22), and 500 cycles at 1 C (b) were 98.6, 95.4, and 91.1%, respectively. Moreover, the Coulombic efficiencies of the batteries are nearly 100% at different current densities. According to our investigation, it is found that polymer electrolytes can hardly achieve high rate cycling performance at low temperature because of the large polarization phenomenon. For all we know, PL/UiOLiTFSI is the first MOF-based SSE which has good electrochemical performance and high Coulombic efficiency at low temperature.

elements.content: Because of the low ion transport capacity and high interface impedance of the electrolyte, it is a great challenge for all-solid-state batteries to operate well at ambient temperature. We tested charge–discharge cycling performance and rate performance of the all-solid-state battery based on the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte at room temperature. For the rate performance, the discharge specific capacities of 137, 120, 92.6, and 52 mA h g–1 are realized at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, and 1 C in the range 2.7–4.0 V (c). As we can see in d, the all-solid-state batteries display high initial discharge capacity of 148 mA h g–1 at 0.1 C. Surprisingly, the Coulombic efficiency of all-solid-state batteries is 98.5% in the first cycle, and the average Coulombic efficiency in the following cycles is about 99.1%, which is higher than the liquid electrolyte. Moreover, the cycle performance at 0.2 C is also presented in Figure S24. The CV curve of the PL/UiOLiTFSI-based batteries exhibits two characteristic peaks near 3.8 and 3.1 V (Figure S25), representing oxidation and reduction scans, respectively. The CV result demonstrates that the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte solid-state batteries not only have reversibility of Li+ transport, but also have outstanding electrochemical stability.

elements.content: In summary, we have proposed a new strategy to design an MOF-based single-ion superionic conductor and then successfully applied it to lithium-ion batteries. Using the PSM method, the large anion, Tf functional group was covalently grafted on the skeleton of UiO-66-NH2, which effectively restricted the movement of anion groups and provided channels for fast and effective transport of Li+. The single-ionic conductor was comprehensively characterized by PXRD, IR, 19F NMR, TG-DSC, and ICP-MS. Importantly, the single-ionic conductor electrolyte exhibits an applicable ionic conductivity at 25 °C (2.07 × 10–4 S cm–1), high ionic transference number (0.84), wide electrochemical window (4.52 V), and excellent dynamic stability. Besides, the prototype Li-metal batteries assembled by the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte exhibit superior rate performance and cycle stability. The discharge specific capacity after 500 cycles of charge–discharge is 132 mA h g–1 (the capacity retention rate is 97.0%) at the current density of 1.0 C. More importantly, the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte shows exciting electrochemical performance and high Coulombic efficiency at low temperature. We believe that the strategy is proposed to achieve more single-ion superionic conductors (including Li+, Na+ and Mg2+ etc.) for next-generation battery devices.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have proposed a new strategy to design an MOF-based single-ion superionic conductor and then successfully applied it to lithium-ion batteries. Using the PSM method, the large anion, Tf functional group was covalently grafted on the skeleton of UiO-66-NH2, which effectively restricted the movement of anion groups and provided channels for fast and effective transport of Li+. The single-ionic conductor was comprehensively characterized by PXRD, IR, 19F NMR, TG-DSC, and ICP-MS. Importantly, the single-ionic conductor electrolyte exhibits an applicable ionic conductivity at 25 °C (2.07 × 10-4 S cm-1), high ionic transference number (0.84), wide electrochemical window (4.52 V), and excellent dynamic stability. Besides, the prototype Li-metal batteries assembled by the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte exhibit superior rate performance and cycle stability. The discharge specific capacity after 500 cycles of charge-discharge is 132 mA h g-1 (the capacity retention rate is 97.0%) at the current density of 1.0 C. More importantly, the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte shows exciting electrochemical performance and high Coulombic efficiency at low temperature. We believe that the strategy is proposed to achieve more single-ion superionic conductors (including Li+, Na+ and Mg2+ etc.) for next-generation battery devices.

The preparation of UiO-66-NH2 was according to a modified reported hydrothermal method. In general, HfCl4 (1.7 g, 5.2 mmol) and 2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.906 g, 5 mmol) were added to 50 mL of a mixed solution of deionized water and acetic acid (volume ratio of 3:2). The mixed solution was refluxed at 100 °C in an oil bath for 24 h to yield light yellow solid powders. The products were collected and washed three times with water, which was activated by heating at 80 °C in vacuum for use.

Synthesis of UiO-66-NHSO<sub>2</sub>CF<sub>3</sub>

To a nanocrystal of UiO-66-NH2 (0.38 g, 1.0 mmol) and triethylamine (0.1518 g, 1.5 mmol) in anhydrous dichloromethane (20 mL) at 0 °C was slowly added trifluoromethanesulfonic anhydride (0.3385 g, 1.2 mmol), and then pyridine (0.0791 g, 1.0 mmol) was added dropwise under stirring conditions. The mixture was maintained at 0 °C for 30 min and then reacted at ambient temperature for 72 h. After the reactions, the sample was collected by centrifugation for further use.

Synthesis of UiO-66-NSO<sub>2</sub>CF<sub>3</sub>K (UiOKTFSI)

The potassium salt form of UiO-66-NSO2CF3K was obtained by neutralization. To a suspended solution of UiO-66-NHSO2CF3 (0.512 g, 1.0 mmol) in deionized water (20 mL) was gradually added slightly excessive K2CO3 powder (0.166 g, 1.2 mmol) at room temperature with stirring for 12 h. The sample was obtained by filtration, and washed two times with water and then heated in 80 °C vacuum overnight.

Synthesis of MOF-Based Single-Ion Conductors (UiOLiTFSI)

The UiOLiTFSI was obtained by ion exchange reaction. The UiO-66-NSO2CF3K (0.55 g, 1.0 mmol) was placed into anhydrous CH3CN (20 mL) in a round-bottom flask, to which was gradually added LiClO4 (0.128 g, 1.2 mmol) at room temperature with stirring for 12 h. The product was filtered and washed with anhydrous acetonitrile several times. Then, the sample was ion-exchanged three times by the same method. Finally, the UiOLiTFSI was obtained by drying at 120 °C in vacuum overnight.

Synthesis of LiUiO-66 (UiOLi)

The UiO-66 was prepared according to a reported method. Typically, terephthalic acid (0.83 g, 5 mmol) and HfCl4 (1.6 g, 5 mmol) were dissolved in 40 mL of mixed solution of dimethylformamide (DMF) and formic acid (volume ratio of 9:1). The mixed solution was put into a stainless-steel autoclave and then heated at 120 °C for 48 h. The product was collected and dried in vacuum at 120 °C; then, it was transferred to the acetonitrile solution of 1 M LiClO4 and stirred for 12 h. The LiUiO-66 obtained was filtered and collected, which was dried by heating at 120 °C in vacuum for use.

cln_elements.content:
Single-ionic conducting electrolytes are important for the improvement of lithium metal batteries with high energy density and safety. Herein, we propose a new strategy to anchor a large anionic group on the skeleton of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and achieve preeminent single-ionic conducting electrolytes. Utilizing a postsynthetic modification method, the trifluoromethanesulfonyl group is covalently coordinated to the amino groups of the UiO-66-NH2 framework. Such a single-ionic conducting solid-state electrolyte (SSE) has a high ionic conductivity (2.07 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 25 °C), a low activation energy of 0.31 eV, a wide electrochemical window up to 4.52 V, as well as a high Li+ transference number of 0.84. Simultaneously, it can effectively inhibit the formation of lithium dendrite. Solid-state batteries assembled with LiFePO4 as the cathode exhibit outstanding rate performance and cyclic stability, especially for low-temperature Li-metal batteries at 0 °C with trace amounts of propylene carbonate as wetting agents. More importantly, the corresponding all-solid-state batteries based on an MOF-based SSE also have nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency at different current densities.

Here, we propose a new strategy and synthesize a novel anionic MOF-based single-ion conducting electrolyte by the postsynthetic modification (PSM) method, in which the trifluoromethylsulfonyl (Tf) group with ion transport property is covalently grafted onto the skeleton of UiO-66-NH2. Because of the strong electron-absorbing effect of the OSO group in Tf, the charge delocalization of a nitrogen atom is enhanced, thus reducing the formation of the lithium-ion pair. In addition, the nanosized MOF-based single-ionic conducting electrolytes can effectively increase the contact between electrolytes and electrodes, thus promoting the interfacial ion transport kinetics. Most impressively, the electrolyte exhibits a splendid ionic conductivity (2.07 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 25 °C), high Li+ transference number (0.84), and effective inhibiting effect for the growth of lithium dendrite. On the basis of the above advantages, the batteries assembled by this SSE have prominent electrochemical performance at low temperature and room temperature. This electrolyte offers the possibility for the practical application of MOF-based electrolytes.

To evaluate the Li+ ionic conductivities of MOF-based single-ion conductors, powder samples were mixed with lithium salt (30% LiTFSI, Li/UiOLiTFSI) and mechanically pressed into pellets (about 550 μm thick, Figure S6a). The corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray mapping images showed that major elements were evenly distributed in the pellet electrolyte (Figure S6b–e). LiTFSI helps improve the interfacial impedance between MOF nanoparticles and provides lithium ion for MOF channels, which can effectively improve the ionic conductivity. At the same time, the solid-state 7Li NMR spectrum also proves that there are two different chemical environments for lithium ion (Figure S7). The ac impedance spectra of the Li/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte were measured at different temperatures (a). The EIS plot at 25 °C shows that the small arc occurring in the high-frequency region (7 MHz to 18 kHz) corresponds to the bulk impedance of the electrolyte, and the straight line in the low-frequency region (18 kHz to 0.1 Hz) is assigned to the interface impedance between the electrolyte and the blocking electrode. Moreover, the EIS plot of the corresponding Li/UiOLi electrolyte was also displayed (Figure S8). The ion conductivities of the Li/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte are 2.07 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 25 °C and 1.39 × 10–3 S cm–1 at 70 °C, which are higher than that of the Li/UiOLi electrolyte (7.95 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 25 °C) and most other porous crystalline material-based solid-state electrolytes (Table S1). The reason can be attributed to the fact that the fixed anions in UiOLiTFSI can separate the ion pairs of LiTFSI, increase the concentration of lithium ions, and improve the ionic conductivity. In addition, the EIS plot of the intrinsic single ionic conductors UiOLiTFSI and UiOLi electrolytes at 25 °C are shown in Figure S9. The ionic conductivities of UiOLiTFSI and UiOLi electrolytes are 1.33 × 10–5 and 8.27 × 10–6 S cm–1, respectively. It is also proved that the addition of lithium salts (LiTFSI) can improve the ionic conductivity. Temperature-dependent conductivity measurements revealed a typical Arrhenius-like activated behavior (b). The activation energies of Li/UiOLiTFSI and Li/UiOLi electrolytes are 0.31 and 0.37 eV, respectively, which are much lower than ceramic-based electrolyte LiPON–Li3PO4 (0.55 eV) and PEO-based polymer electrolyte (1.66 eV). With a high conductivity (10–4 S cm–1) and a low activation energy (less than 0.4 eV), the new Li/UiOLiTFSI solid electrolyte can be defined as a superionic conductor.

Considering the practical application, we fabricated a flexible free-standing single-ion conductor membrane by mixing Li/UiOLiTFSI and Li/UiOLi with 20% polytetrafluoroethylene (PVDF) as a binder, and the membranes were named as PL/UiOLiTFSI and PL/UiOLi. As shown in Figure S10, the electrolyte membrane has excellent flexibility and mechanical strength. Meanwhile, the residual solvent in the electrolyte membrane was detected by the 1H NMR spectrum (Figure S11), and the peaks of the residual solvents (2.73, 2.89, and 7.95 ppm) were so weak that they could almost be ignored. The nanoparticles of Li/UiOLiTFSI were uniformly distributed in the PVDF matrix with a smooth surface, as evidenced by the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image and the thickness of the electrolyte membrane is about 60–70 μm (c–e), which was formed by the accumulation of UiOLiTFSI nanoparticles. The electrochemical window of PL/UiOLiTFSI and the corresponding PL/UiOLi electrolyte membranes were investigated through linear sweep voltammograms (LSV) at room temperature (f). The stainless steel and lithium sheets were used as working and reference electrodes, respectively. The stable voltage of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte is about 4.52 V, which is obviously higher than that of the PL/UiOLi electrolyte (≈4.13 V). The cyclic voltammertry (CV) test further confirmed the chemical stability of the electrolytes. As shown in Figure S13, a pair of reversible redox current peaks near 0 V represent the dissolution and deposition of lithium ions on the working electrode. The oxidation current peak near 4.52 V is attributed to the decomposition of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte, which is consistent with LSV results. However, the electrochemical window of the intrinsic single ionic conductor electrolyte (P/UiOLiTFSI) without lithium salt is 4.08 V (Figure S12). The broad electrochemical window and high electrochemical stability is conducive to the matching of cathode materials with high-voltage lithium batteries.

Other key parameters for electrolyte materials, lithium-ion transport number (t Li+ ) of PL/UiOLiTFSI and PL/UiOLi were measured using Li|SSEs|Li symmetric cells by the Evans method at room temperature and calculated by the current–time curve and the ac impedance spectra before and after polarization. The t Li+ of PL/UiOLiTFSI was 0.84, which is higher than that of PL/UiOLi (0.59) and other reported porous crystalline materials (g, S15, and Table S1). The high t Li+ value is ascribed to the restricted movement of large anion groups (Tf) grafted on the MOF skeleton as well as super single-ion conducting property, which can effectively overcome the polarization of batteries caused by the anionic motion. Meanwhile, the result was also confirmed by galvanostatic charge and discharge. In addition, the lithium ion transport number (0.87) under solvent-free conditions was measured, as shown in Figure S14. Combining with high lithium-ion transport number and wide electrochemical window, the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte is suitable for practical application in solid-state batteries, especially for fast-charging solid-state lithium batteries.

cln_elements.content:
To investigate the practical application of the MOF-based electrolyte in lithium metal batteries, the dynamic stabilities of the Li/electrolyte interface were tested by galvanostatic cycling experiments of Li symmetric batteries. The positive and negative voltages represent lithium stripping and deposition, respectively. Despite their high ionic conductivity, sulfide electrolytes exhibit poor lithium stability because of high interfacial impedance and obvious interfacial reaction. In contrast, the MOF-based single ion conductor electrolytes exhibit excellent interfacial stability. As shown in a, the Li|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li cell exhibits an excellent cycle stability at a current density of 0.05 mA cm–2 at room temperature. The average polarization voltage response is as low as 0.02 V. Even at the cycle time up to 160 h, the cell remains stable and has no obvious irreversible fluctuation of polarization voltage. Also, the SEM image of the lithium electrode after the Li plating/stripping cycling test exhibits very smooth and dense surface morphology (d). When the current density increases to 0.075 mA cm–2 (b), 0.15 mA cm–2 (c), and 0.3 mA cm–2 (Figure S16), the polarization voltage increases slightly, but there is still no short-circuit behavior. As the current density increases to 0.4 mA cm–2, the polarization voltage increases significantly after 23 h until the battery is forced to stop (Figure S16). In addition, the symmetrical battery is short-circuited after 46 h at the current density of 0.05 mA cm–2 for the intrinsic single ionic conductor electrolyte (P/UiOLiTFSI) without lithium salt (Figure S17). With respect to the full battery, short circuit occurs after six cycles of battery cycle at a current density of 0.2 C (Figure S20). However, as shown in Figure S18, the Li|PL/UiOLi|Li cell has a higher polarization voltage and a larger voltage fluctuation compared with the Li|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li cell. This implies that the interface between the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte and lithium metal is unstable. Some stick-shaped lithium dendrites on the surface of Li metal electrode are obviously observed (e). This is because in the process of lithium deposition, cations near the lithium electrode are reduced by electrons from the surface of lithium electrodes, and anions are expelled by the electric field; when the salt concentration near the electrode drops to zero within a certain period of time (Sand’s time), the charge balance of the electrolyte is destroyed, thereby resulting in the growth of lithium dendrites. Therefore, because of the high t Li+ of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte, the concentration of Li+ near the lithium electrode can be increased and the Sand’s time can be prolonged, thus resulting in excellent interface stability and compatibility of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte. These results confirmed that the high lithium-ion transport number and good dynamic stability of electrolyte are responsible for restriction of Li dendrite growth and promotion of Li deposition uniformly. However, because of the existence of lithium salts, the addition of trace PC solvents will lead to high concentration of liquid electrolyte, which will promote the conduction of lithium ions. In order to avoid appeal factors, the lithium-stripping deposition experiment of the solventless PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte was tested. As shown in Figure S23, the symmetrical battery can be stable for 120 h at a current density of 0.025 mA cm–2. Therefore, the single ionic conductor electrolyte has excellent electrochemical stability.

In order to show the potential application of the MOF-based single ionic conductor electrolyte in lithium battery, we assembled solid-state lithium batteries, with LFP cathode and Li anode, to evaluate the performance of MOF-based electrolytes. The LFP|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li battery exhibited an excellent cycling performance (a), delivering a capacity of 147.7 mA h g–1 after 100 cycles at room temperature (97.2% to the initial capacity of 152 mA h g–1). Moreover, the Coulombic efficiency was improved from 95.1% of the first cycle to 99.5% of the subsequent cycle, which indicated that the electrolyte and electrode had good interface stability. Moreover, the rate performances of the LFP|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li battery are 145, 141, 136 and 109 mA h g–1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, and 3.0 C, respectively (b). Even after 10 cycles at high rates at 3.0 C, the battery recovered the capacity of 140 mA h g–1 at 0.1 C, demonstrating a good reversibility. What is more, the polarization of the charge curve of the battery system assembled by the PL/UiOLi electrolyte is obviously larger than that of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte (c). In addition, this polarization behavior is also lower than that of other MOF-based electrolyte battery systems, which is attributed to the high Li+ transport number of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte compared with other MOF-based electrolytes. It is worth mentioning that the battery maintained 97.0% capacity intention after 500 cycles of charge–discharge at 1.0 C (d), showing a good long-term cycling performance. However, the batteries of the PL/UiOLi electrolyte system have a very large capacity attenuation after 50 cycles. Interestingly, solid-state batteries in both systems showed various degrees of capacity increase within the first few dozen cycles, possibly because of the fitting of electrode and electrolyte interfaces. Finally, the PXRD results of PL/UiOLiTFSI and PL/UiOLi electrolytes after 100 cycles show that the crystal structure and topological structure of MOFs are still perfectly maintained (Figure S19).

Low-temperature performance is an important indicator of SSE because the traditional solid-state batteries can only work well at temperatures above room temperature. In order to study the adaptability of the MOF-based SSE under different temperatures, we investigated the electrochemical charge–discharge performance of the LFP|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li battery at 0 °C. To our satisfaction, the solid-state batteries assembled from the MOF-based SSE show high rate performance and discharge capacity at 0 °C. As the current rate increases to 2 C, the discharge capacity of solid-state batteries remains 56 mA h g–1 at 0 °C. As the current rate returns to 0.1 C, the discharge capacity approaches its initial capacity (a). The discharge capacity retention rates of the solid-state batteries for 90 cycles at 0.2 C (Figure S21), 120 cycles at 0.5 C (Figure S22), and 500 cycles at 1 C (b) were 98.6, 95.4, and 91.1%, respectively. Moreover, the Coulombic efficiencies of the batteries are nearly 100% at different current densities. According to our investigation, it is found that polymer electrolytes can hardly achieve high rate cycling performance at low temperature because of the large polarization phenomenon. For all we know, PL/UiOLiTFSI is the first MOF-based SSE which has good electrochemical performance and high Coulombic efficiency at low temperature.

Because of the low ion transport capacity and high interface impedance of the electrolyte, it is a great challenge for all-solid-state batteries to operate well at ambient temperature. We tested charge–discharge cycling performance and rate performance of the all-solid-state battery based on the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte at room temperature. For the rate performance, the discharge specific capacities of 137, 120, 92.6, and 52 mA h g–1 are realized at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, and 1 C in the range 2.7–4.0 V (c). As we can see in d, the all-solid-state batteries display high initial discharge capacity of 148 mA h g–1 at 0.1 C. Surprisingly, the Coulombic efficiency of all-solid-state batteries is 98.5% in the first cycle, and the average Coulombic efficiency in the following cycles is about 99.1%, which is higher than the liquid electrolyte. Moreover, the cycle performance at 0.2 C is also presented in Figure S24. The CV curve of the PL/UiOLiTFSI-based batteries exhibits two characteristic peaks near 3.8 and 3.1 V (Figure S25), representing oxidation and reduction scans, respectively. The CV result demonstrates that the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte solid-state batteries not only have reversibility of Li+ transport, but also have outstanding electrochemical stability.

Conclusions

In summary, we have proposed a new strategy to design an MOF-based single-ion superionic conductor and then successfully applied it to lithium-ion batteries. Using the PSM method, the large anion, Tf functional group was covalently grafted on the skeleton of UiO-66-NH2, which effectively restricted the movement of anion groups and provided channels for fast and effective transport of Li+. The single-ionic conductor was comprehensively characterized by PXRD, IR, 19F NMR, TG-DSC, and ICP-MS. Importantly, the single-ionic conductor electrolyte exhibits an applicable ionic conductivity at 25 °C (2.07 × 10–4 S cm–1), high ionic transference number (0.84), wide electrochemical window (4.52 V), and excellent dynamic stability. Besides, the prototype Li-metal batteries assembled by the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte exhibit superior rate performance and cycle stability. The discharge specific capacity after 500 cycles of charge–discharge is 132 mA h g–1 (the capacity retention rate is 97.0%) at the current density of 1.0 C. More importantly, the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte shows exciting electrochemical performance and high Coulombic efficiency at low temperature. We believe that the strategy is proposed to achieve more single-ion superionic conductors (including Li+, Na+ and Mg2+ etc.) for next-generation battery devices.

In contrast, the MOF-based single ion conductor electrolytes exhibit excellent interfacial stability. As shown in a, the Li|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li cell exhibits an excellent cycle stability at a current density of 0.05 mA cm-2 at room temperature. The average polarization voltage response is as low as 0.02 V. Even at the cycle time up to 160 h, the cell remains stable and has no obvious irreversible fluctuation of polarization voltage. Also, the SEM image of the lithium electrode after the Li plating/stripping cycling test exhibits very smooth and dense surface morphology (d). When the current density increases to 0.075 mA cm-2 (b), 0.15 mA cm-2 (c), and 0.3 mA cm-2 (Figure S16), the polarization voltage increases slightly, but there is still no short-circuit behavior. As the current density increases to 0.4 mA cm-2, the polarization voltage increases significantly after 23 h until the battery is forced to stop (Figure S16). In addition, the symmetrical battery is short-circuited after 46 h at the current density of 0.05 mA cm-2 for the intrinsic single ionic conductor electrolyte (P/UiOLiTFSI) without lithium salt (Figure S17). With respect to the full battery, short circuit occurs after six cycles of battery cycle at a current density of 0.2 C (Figure S20). However, as shown in Figure S18, the Li|PL/UiOLi|Li cell has a higher polarization voltage and a larger voltage fluctuation compared with the Li|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li cell. This implies that the interface between the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte and lithium metal is unstable. Some stick-shaped lithium dendrites on the surface of Li metal electrode are obviously observed (e). This is because in the process of lithium deposition, cations near the lithium electrode are reduced by electrons from the surface of lithium electrodes, and anions are expelled by the electric field; when the salt concentration near the electrode drops to zero within a certain period of time (Sand's time), the charge balance of the electrolyte is destroyed, thereby resulting in the growth of lithium dendrites. Therefore, because of the high t Li+  of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte, the concentration of Li+ near the lithium electrode can be increased and the Sand's time can be prolonged, thus resulting in excellent interface stability and compatibility of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte. These results confirmed that the high lithium-ion transport number and good dynamic stability of electrolyte are responsible for restriction of Li dendrite growth and promotion of Li deposition uniformly. However, because of the existence of lithium salts, the addition of trace PC solvents will lead to high concentration of liquid electrolyte, which will promote the conduction of lithium ions. In order to avoid appeal factors, the lithium-stripping deposition experiment of the solventless PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte was tested. As shown in Figure S23, the symmetrical battery can be stable for 120 h at a current density of 0.025 mA cm-2. Therefore, the single ionic conductor electrolyte has excellent electrochemical stability.

In order to show the potential application of the MOF-based single ionic conductor electrolyte in lithium battery, we assembled solid-state lithium batteries, with LFP cathode and Li anode, to evaluate the performance of MOF-based electrolytes. The LFP|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li battery exhibited an excellent cycling performance (a), delivering a capacity of 147.7 mA h g-1 after 100 cycles at room temperature (97.2% to the initial capacity of 152 mA h g-1). Moreover, the Coulombic efficiency was improved from 95.1% of the first cycle to 99.5% of the subsequent cycle, which indicated that the electrolyte and electrode had good interface stability. Moreover, the rate performances of the LFP|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li battery are 145, 141, 136 and 109 mA h g-1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, and 3.0 C, respectively (b). Even after 10 cycles at high rates at 3.0 C, the battery recovered the capacity of 140 mA h g-1 at 0.1 C, demonstrating a good reversibility. What is more, the polarization of the charge curve of the battery system assembled by the PL/UiOLi electrolyte is obviously larger than that of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte (c). In addition, this polarization behavior is also lower than that of other MOF-based electrolyte battery systems, which is attributed to the high Li+ transport number of the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte compared with other MOF-based electrolytes. It is worth mentioning that the battery maintained 97.0% capacity intention after 500 cycles of charge-discharge at 1.0 C (d), showing a good long-term cycling performance. However, the batteries of the PL/UiOLi electrolyte system have a very large capacity attenuation after 50 cycles. Interestingly, solid-state batteries in both systems showed various degrees of capacity increase within the first few dozen cycles, possibly because of the fitting of electrode and electrolyte interfaces. Finally, the PXRD results of PL/UiOLiTFSI and PL/UiOLi electrolytes after 100 cycles show that the crystal structure and topological structure of MOFs are still perfectly maintained (Figure S19).

Low-temperature performance is an important indicator of SSE because the traditional solid-state batteries can only work well at temperatures above room temperature. In order to study the adaptability of the MOF-based SSE under different temperatures, we investigated the electrochemical charge-discharge performance of the LFP|PL/UiOLiTFSI|Li battery at 0 °C. To our satisfaction, the solid-state batteries assembled from the MOF-based SSE show high rate performance and discharge capacity at 0 °C. As the current rate increases to 2 C, the discharge capacity of solid-state batteries remains 56 mA h g-1 at 0 °C. As the current rate returns to 0.1 C, the discharge capacity approaches its initial capacity (a). The discharge capacity retention rates of the solid-state batteries for 90 cycles at 0.2 C (Figure S21), 120 cycles at 0.5 C (Figure S22), and 500 cycles at 1 C (b) were 98.6, 95.4, and 91.1%, respectively. Moreover, the Coulombic efficiencies of the batteries are nearly 100% at different current densities. According to our investigation, it is found that polymer electrolytes can hardly achieve high rate cycling performance at low temperature because of the large polarization phenomenon. For all we know, PL/UiOLiTFSI is the first MOF-based SSE which has good electrochemical performance and high Coulombic efficiency at low temperature.

Because of the low ion transport capacity and high interface impedance of the electrolyte, it is a great challenge for all-solid-state batteries to operate well at ambient temperature. We tested charge-discharge cycling performance and rate performance of the all-solid-state battery based on the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte at room temperature. For the rate performance, the discharge specific capacities of 137, 120, 92.6, and 52 mA h g-1 are realized at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, and 1 C in the range 2.7-4.0 V (c). As we can see in d, the all-solid-state batteries display high initial discharge capacity of 148 mA h g-1 at 0.1 C. Surprisingly, the Coulombic efficiency of all-solid-state batteries is 98.5% in the first cycle, and the average Coulombic efficiency in the following cycles is about 99.1%, which is higher than the liquid electrolyte. Moreover, the cycle performance at 0.2 C is also presented in Figure S24. The CV curve of the PL/UiOLiTFSI-based batteries exhibits two characteristic peaks near 3.8 and 3.1 V (Figure S25), representing oxidation and reduction scans, respectively. The CV result demonstrates that the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte solid-state batteries not only have reversibility of Li+ transport, but also have outstanding electrochemical stability.

Conclusions

In summary, we have proposed a new strategy to design an MOF-based single-ion superionic conductor and then successfully applied it to lithium-ion batteries. Using the PSM method, the large anion, Tf functional group was covalently grafted on the skeleton of UiO-66-NH2, which effectively restricted the movement of anion groups and provided channels for fast and effective transport of Li+. The single-ionic conductor was comprehensively characterized by PXRD, IR, 19F NMR, TG-DSC, and ICP-MS. Importantly, the single-ionic conductor electrolyte exhibits an applicable ionic conductivity at 25 °C (2.07 × 10-4 S cm-1), high ionic transference number (0.84), wide electrochemical window (4.52 V), and excellent dynamic stability. Besides, the prototype Li-metal batteries assembled by the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte exhibit superior rate performance and cycle stability. The discharge specific capacity after 500 cycles of charge-discharge is 132 mA h g-1 (the capacity retention rate is 97.0%) at the current density of 1.0 C. More importantly, the PL/UiOLiTFSI electrolyte shows exciting electrochemical performance and high Coulombic efficiency at low temperature. We believe that the strategy is proposed to achieve more single-ion superionic conductors (including Li+, Na+ and Mg2+ etc.) for next-generation battery devices.
